description.text:
This is a trackside cabinet and hall effect sensor holder to help automate a Garden Railway.
The sensor fits standard 45mm Gscale track.
The electronics is a NodeMCU, which fits in the cabinet, and has a HALL sensor fiitted in the center of the track. When a loco with a suitable magnet passes over the sensor, it sends a signal to the railway controller to indicate that the line is occupied.
I have used a hall sensor as it should be reliable, although it will need good sealing from rain etc. My previous sensors were current sensing which was great, but my Tram does not take current from the track, so is not able to be seen by this method. By changing to magnetic sensing, all my locos can now work together. I have used 25mm circular magnets mounted on the locos with epoxy, but other magnets will work. Be sure to have the hall sensors all in the same orientation, and that all the magnets are correctly oriented to activate the sensors.

The NodeMCU consumes about 10mA when running so it can be powered from batteries. My code for the ESP8266 allows for up to 8 I/O which can be hall sensors, or outputs such as servos or PWM or on/off for lights, signals etc. Using Wireless allows easy movement of the hardware, but for ultimate reliability, you should use wired sensors, and there are plenty of commercial and DIY alternatives to my NodeMCU powered system presented here. When an IO is set as Input, it also activates an internal pull up, so the simplest "circuit" is just the NodeMCU plus a Battery and a "3144" Hall effect sensor.
To drive a servo, for example, for points, the i/o port is set to "servo" and directly coupled to the servo, the output is 3.3V, but most servos seem to accept this. The Servo power must be 5V, and a separate power supply for this is recommended. I simply used 4AA batteries to power the servo and NodeMCU for my tests.

If you want to try it, the current (and very experimental) code for the NodeMCU is in https://github.com/dagnall53/RocNetNodeAutoConnect, but please check to see if there is an update, as the MQTT broker search I have implemented is crude and I plan to update this soon. You will need a PC running RocRail (http://wiki.rocrail.net/doku.php) , set to use a "RocNet" Controller with the MQTT interface, and a MQTT broker, such as Mosquitto to accept and pass the NodeMCU signals back and forwards to RocRail.
Here is a Video of it working with my tram, and two sensors all connected with NodeMCU interfaces.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C6bxuHB6rpU

author: Kumardebu

title: Toranado Extruder Digital Depth Z Gauge mount

description.text:
For Toranado Extruder V2 ... a tool mount adapter for accurately measuring 3D Printer bed level & flatness. Makes use of the Toranado V2 pluggable hotend mount feature. Simply pull out your hotend, and insert this digital depth gage & adapter mount, then screw clamp it in place just like the hotend is mounted!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246951/
...relative to the extuder hotend mounting features. This digital gage adapter mounts in the Toranado V2 removeable hot end clamp, using that single screw to lock it in place. Simply pull out the Toranado V2 hotend, and replace it with this gage tool ... then measure your print bed.

The digital gage is inexpensive and accurate, gages on ebay currently for sale listed here:
http://BigCooter.com/gage/
(make sure you purchase the one that looks like the one in the Thing files here, some similar appearing gages do not have the mounting feature on the backside)

A reasonably accurate 3D model of this gage is included here, which may be used to facilitate the design of other gage accessories, use as you wish.

Note there is an option for fixing the gage to the printed adaptor block, this requires drilling one M3 clearance hole in the gage. Then a M3 screw can be used to clamp the gage to the block .. for the convenience of keeping your block and gauge as a single aligned unit.

Personally, I have found this tool very useful for check the flatness of the print bed. While auto leveling can be a great feature, variations in the bed flatness can not be compensated for. This tool allows mapping the print bed, and then making appropriate adjustments by machine or by hand to achieve a low flatness variation across the bed. This can be accomplished with bed made of PEI, Aluminum, etc.. (not glass of course!) ... even by hand sanding, it is easy to achieve a bed flatness of 0.05mm max total variation ... this greatly improves the potential first layer print quality over the entire bed, for parts that require good cosmetic appearance on that surface. (like my http://Vidit360.com panoramic camera parts)

Notice - this adaptor component was remixed with the permission of Toranado3D (current license does not allow unauthorized remixing of Toranado3D extruder files listed on Thingiverse).

description.text: Tactile graphics made from this source image as a starting point, using this script to create STL objects from colored patches in the image. The ZIP files contain the images and partial files needed to create the finished STL files. The prints were made on a Ultimaker 2 printer.

This is a modification to the Air 2 - Jordan to allow for 1/8th (11 gage) steel to be cut. I've cut off all the side tabs and adjusted the holes accordingly (I hope..hehe). The two bottom bracket holes on the side plates were replaced with actual circles as it looked like they were hand drawn in.  
I plan on having my unit plated or powder coated depending how the cuts turn out and how tight the fit is. In turn, the structure can now be tack welded together for a super strong/riged frame.
Bill of materials would be the same as the Air 2. The drawings have been modified to work with 1/8th (11 gage) steel.

remixed_from.author: jadames
remixed_from.title: Z rod cap for Anet A6

title: Dust Cap for Z-Rod Anet A6, for free movement of Z-Rod without catching dust from above.

description.text:
I was wondering, why the z-rods are the only parts in the Anet A6-Setup, that looks as if they have been forgotten and left standing in some holes. See pictures above without the caps.
So I designed and printed some caps, fitting inside the Anet A6's acrylic-frame.
They are as thin as possible to just cover the holes, giving the z-rods enough space above and to the sides to move free. So they will not get the dust from above, but is not hindered in his movement. As designer Eriobis has mentioned here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1610611/#comments and 1BigE mentioned here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1473965/#comments , the z-rod is not to be forced at that point!

I learned, that designer jadames has designed and published his very similar caps and take the other approach by building a tight fit around the rods. I am referencing to him as a remix-source, since he does the same with mine to point to the two different approaches possible. Which one is best for clearing out the wobble will maybe be shown at a direct comparison later. Anyone that might want to test both and share his results is welcome to post them into the comments :)

Designed with 123D Design. Sliced with Cura.
Resolution 0.2 - everything else quite standard settings, for it is just a small part.
Did I mention: You've GOT to print two of them! ;o)

The print in the pictures is not my final. It was printed before some more upgrades that stabilized my x-wobble. Have a look at my other designs soon.

comments.text: hackezkk has posted a solution to make them fit the A8-holes. For dust protection (and design-completion) only, of course! :D
comments.author: MrMoehre

comments.text:
I designed a similar part myself, although I put 0.5mm clearance on the inner and outer holes. I haven't run into z-axis wobble problems at all yet, with or without the caps. I haven't printed any particularly tall things yet though. If anything they just make it look a bit neater.
On the Anet A6 the x-axis belt is not in line with Z axis guide and threaded rods. This means the force from the X axis belt creates a twisting torque on the Z axis carriage which acts to push the threaded rods towards the front of the printer and the guide rods to the back. In that regard the Z axis threaded rod is already constrained at the top so having the larger hole may not help much but I don't really know to be honest.
comments.author: BrienAllison

comments.text: I absolutely agree with you. It should only be designed for cosmetic reasons, never for "anti wobble", because it could not fullfill that.
comments.author: BrienAllison

comments.text: I very much disagree. I do not have comparison, but the leading rods are in charge of keeping the x-axel in place, not the driving rod. From where  I am looking at it, also printing in big hights the threaded rod has to spin free, not being forced by bearings.
comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text: We saw a big improvement when we mounted those stabilizers to our Prusa. I see that yours is similar. You cannot stabilize it without bearings because the z-rod will try to bolt into the stabilizer. So I guess you could come up with a remix of our thing that will satisfy you. What this will give you is stability in higher prints. The higher you go, the more shake you get...

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount for FT-5 or any 2020 extrusion

description.text:
In conjunction with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1867512 , the cradle for a Raspberry Pi 3 set up, I needed a mount for the Raspi camera that would fit the top 2020 extrusion on the Folger Tech FT-5. This mounts and snaps in place to hold the camera at a good angle to see the build surface. It holds this camera case > http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:472028. Although it says it for the NOIR version, it really makes no difference what camera goes inside.
Since I had the Volcano hot end in place with a 0.8 mm nozzle, that's what I used with ESUN PLA+. It is very strong and flexible enough to snap in place.

PS: I had to tilt the holder back 5 degrees to get a better view of the nozzle. That's reflected in the files now.

PPS: I added another 5 degrees to maximize the view from the middle rail, rather than the top rail. It is the 'revised' version.

description.text:
Modelo de Federico Muñoz para el Proyectual "Micromundos" de 2016
https://catedracaceresuna.wordpress.com/federico-munoz/
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9CuXws5NwWQ

This is a fully printable 3.5 audio jack socket that connects directly to breadboard jumpers.

I was looking for a cable to connect components of another project and decided to use standard audio cables - they are available everywhere, are relatively cheap and you can get them at any length.

The connectors for them are also pretty cheap at all the regular Chinese sites, but, it takes around 2 month for stuff to get here from china so I decided to design my own printable version.

When I looked for something to use as the leads inside the connector I got the bright idea to use breadboard jumpers, this means there aren't additional non-printable parts and that it's very easy to use with a solderless breadboard.

It works really well, I didn't test the durability of this design.

I printed in PLA, 0.2 layer height, 0.4 muzzle, 100% infill, no supports (I believe it will work better and be more durable in ABS, PETG or Nylon, but I haven't tried)

This is a tiny model with a somewhat complex geometry, so layer cooling is a problem - print slowly and with all the cooling you can get, I turned the speed down to 70% of my usual speed and turned on the air conditioner, you can clearly see the difference between the slower printed part and the normal speed one.

Push the jumpers into the holes in the recessed side, there's a springy thing on the other side that's supposed to hold them, a little bit of hot glue will help if the jumpers fall out.

The outside (the side the connector goes into) is the flat side with the round hole in the middle that should be on the buildplate.

There are two small bumps 1.2mm from the edge on two sides to help hold the socket in place, those are only 0.8mm wide for easy printing.

The hole size is 9.6x11.2mm (plus a little bit for tolerance).

Designed with SketchUp, Sliced with Cura and printed on my Robo3D R1+

title: Tile Tray for Castle Ravenloft Board Game

description.text:
This is the start of a larger project. It serves as a tray for when playing on the table, but also for storage within the box.

I am going to remove the flimsy black plastic insert that comes with the game and design & print an entire set of storage trays, much like I did with my Pandemic game recently here on Thingiverse.

The other storage trays I need to print are the one for the dragon, the construct & zombie dragon. For all the cards (sleeved). For all the chits.

And most importantly, storage trays for the miniatures, each with their own little padded cubby to protect paint.. I plan on using grey craft foam and adhereing to the 3D print out (within each cubby).

Enjoy.

EDIT: The top corners are a bit pointy and can be uncomfortable to hand if you aren't careful placing or removing tiles from the stack. So I just used a small jeweler's file and rounded all the corners and smoothed / polished. If someone wants to modify the SCAD file to round the upper corners, I'll update the SCAD file here with the new one -- or you can remix.

comments.text: Just made one, and it looks fantastic.  Can't wait to see what else you have in store for a replacement insert!

description.text: Stacked two adapters so either size can be used..

I created this to gain some more z-height.
There should be an extra of 30mm since the carriage wont hit the frame anymore.
The version with the orignial bearing blocks is less because of the rear bearing hitting the frame at the angeled edges.
The other version is for bronze bushings, wich run much smoother. I tried even Igus but they only got the right tolerances if they are pushed into a fitting.

The extruder mount is designed to use a LED-heatsink, so no more jamming will happen on the Geeetech MK8 extruder.

You can simply use the orignial rods.
The spindle needs to be a trapedizional one with proper nuts (photo attached). May edit this part for your needs.
If you use the original couplings on the z-motors, use the foots to lift the mashine.

There is a inductive sensor mount right next to the nozzle.

Make whatever you want with this.

The fan shroud is a little bit buggy, you should touch this.

description.text: The wires from the Z stage on the Makerbot Thing-O-Matic are free to rub on the edges and screws of the Makerbot.  These wire clips keep the wires from rubbing on anything and are flexible enough to follow the Z stage.

• Print out one of these clips (the defaults should print just fine)
  • Clip to the top of the Makerbot or close fascimile
  • Position one of the wires in the clip
  • Move the Z-stage all the way up and down to make sure that the clips behave as expected -- the clip is intended to flex and twist
  • Yell "Look upon my works, ye mighty, and despair!"
  • Apologize to the cat, who is strangely unimpressed
Just a tiny enhancement to the original mount from mafe68. It was a bit off in size. I corrected that. Now it fits perfect.

print_settings.Notes:: It's pretty tiny, with some small detail, so print with as fine a resolution as your printer can manage.

description.text:
Every November we Canadians (and residents of other Commonwealth countries) wear a red poppy leading up to Remembrance Day, November 11. When we buy a poppy, and wear it around, we feel good about remembering those who served honourably in our military. But there are two poppy-wearin' problems:

  • The poppies fall off really easily
  • The pin can sometimes poke you painfully

3D printing comes to the rescue!
I've designed a tiny little poppy-shaped end for your pin to both hold it in place, and protect you from spearing a valued body part. It'll use about a gram of filament. :)

I've only printed it in white PLA - but would love to see it in another colour - red anyone?

Features and Options:

  • Other printing options
    • match the filament to your jacket or shirt colour to downplay the pin cap.
    • use a bright colour to emphasize it
    • the centre bit is slightly higher. If you can time it right, you could print in red, then pause and SWAP FILAMENT to black before finishing the last couple of layers. Would LOVE to see someone pull that off and share results
  • A Canadian abroad, or resident of a poppy-less country? Just use a regular pin and you can wear a tiny little poppy to show you remember and value your ancestor's wartime sacrifices.

The pic with black background is the version2 print. I added a few details and tweaks for the shared v3 file, shown against white graph-paper.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.05

Infill:

30%

Notes:

It's pretty tiny, with some small detail, so print with as fine a resolution as your printer can manage.

The hole for the pin might be a bit tight, but that's good for best retention. Just push it in hard and it should be good. Will likely loosen up as you do multiple swaps, but hope it still holds on okay. The hole tapers inside, so should work long term. Still, it's pretty fine geometry in there, so not sure how well rendered it would be.

comments.text: Was going to accept your challenge of printing it in red with a black centre, but, the poppy itself is lopsided and therefore can't be done.

This is a Firewall enforcement for the Durafly Excalibur sold by HobbyKing.
I think it's a great plane for the money, but sadly enough they sold them with a motor mount that's too weak to take the forces when the motor starts and stops.
After a few flights I had mine broken out and I had it crash landed.

I bought a new cowling, I cut a plate out of 2mm woven carbon fibre and placed it on the outside of the motor. Because I kept the same dimensions, the propellor is moved 1 or 2mm to the front.
Someone at my club liked the Excalibur so much that he bought one as well.
For this reason I decided to print one for him with the help of a friend who's good with SolidWorks.
We both didn't have the Excalibur at hand, but the dimensions should fit.

I think it's easy to make a design that just doesn't break whatever force you put to it. It's harder to make something that is just enough.

That's what I did with this design. Together with the original motor mount this should be just enough to prevent the experience that I and some others had. On top of that It is easy to mount and it doesn't change the dimensions.

I would replace the screws with some nice titanium bolts with cylinder heads just like I did. Put some glue between the dish and the original motor mount. I used Foam-Tac, but other glue that stays a bit flexible will do fine.

I made a V2 after noticing some little things when actually mounting.

It is 3mm instead of 2mm thick (which should still fit nicely)
It has some extra room for the extender shaft. It should be able to go 2 mm inside.
The bolts have now 3.1mm (was 3.0) for the hole and the sunked in part is now 5.2 (instead of 5). The ventilation holes are now straight holes to make it stronger.

Printer:

Mendelflex

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used ABS-PC (ABS with Polycarbonate), but ABS will do fine.
PLA probably works too, but is somewhat brittle and also weakens a lot when warmed.
I would recommend to use ABS at least.

description.text:
A replacement wheel (about 70mm in diameter) for the ubiquitous yellow cheap robotic gear motor / wheel combo.
This was printed in TPU, a flexible filament similar to semi-flex. The deflection of this wheel under load is very similar to the wheel it replaces. It could be printed in a hard filament like PLA but it would have much less grip.
There are customizers on Thingiverse that allow you to set custom dimensions for a wheel like this but none of them produce a wheel with tread.
A brief video of this wheel in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8Mmn6bkTCo
For more projects see: http://www.robot50.net

title: LeXY - Core XY 3D printer Update Package

description.text:
I just build my LeXY printer wich is overall great.

The mounting points in the edges where a bit to flexible for my understanding, I constructed some stiffers.
I got some trouble with the big tolerances around the bushings and the rods so I want to share the required parts with some tighter measurements.

There are some parts still in progress, like the remix of the Ultimaker 2 Spool holder and therefore the internal fillament spool.
I'll need to make a fillament guide.

The whole top will be covered in plexiglas so I'm able to print ABS easily.

The base needs to be covered up, there will be some fix for that soon.

The front door hinge is for a 5mm plexiglas.

The camera mount will soon be updated to a new HD cam (currently taped on)

Some proper cable management is needed ^^ I know

author: Kev0

print_settings.Notes:: the first and last data point are labeled, but on my print this is unreadable due to the choice of material.

description.text:
this is a 3D object of the global temperature change between 1850 and 2016. it is based on the same data as the famous »climate spiral« by ed hawkins (1), so if you want to know details, go there and read up on all the details.

it's a pretty scary thing to hold in your hand and feel how obvious global warming is, and how we are not even close to a turning point.

(1) http://www.climate-lab-book.ac.uk/2016/spiralling-global-temperatures/ -

[edit] i resized the object along the x-axis by 200%, and the spiral character of it is now much more better recognizable. can be done in your slicer of choice.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

print took 18h18m. print-orientation was more or less horizontal, using the »lay flat« option of makerware. this minimized supports, making them easier to remove with simple pliers. used a spark plug brush to remove residuals.

the first and last data point are labeled, but on my print this is unreadable due to the choice of material.

this model was created by importing the original data into a spreadsheet (iworks numbers, to be concrete), interpreting them as polar coordinates and converting them to cartesian coordinates, with a counter for Z so that the resulting object actually will be a spiral and not a series of disks. still in the spreadsheet, i added the necessary text padding around the numbers to then create an STL file by copy/pasting the text into a text file. it was surprisingly simple in the end.

after a couple of iterations, the current form was finalized. i closed the top & bottom using sketchup.

comments.text: Get the more accurate chart that logs the temperature from 400,000bc through to todays date and it will give you a true reflection. Based on the full chart (This is only a very small section of the actual chart that was originally used) you will be able to see where it will end up. I will see if I can make a model of the full chart and print it. Will add as a remix of this.

description.text:
I saw fidget toys and spinners so I tried to make one of my own.

The bigger one is 25mm, the smaller one is 20mm. I'm only 5ft0in so I thought that would be small enough for someone my size. Other people have made caps for the bearings so I made some of those too. They might need to be sanded smooth.

Amazon has loads of different sized bearings, I designed these around "694Z Metal Shields Sealed Deep Groove Ball Bearings 4 x 11 x 4mm 10Pcs" so the dips on the sides are 11mm wide and 4mm deep.

I don't have a 3D printer so I can't test it. Sorry about the bad pictures.

description.text:
Wire stripper. Not very beautiful (this is too big blade for this tool), but works well. All you need is M3 screw, M3 nut, and utility blade.

UPDATE: Made version 2 - stronger and without useless trigger. :) I suggest to use supports while printing for M3 nut hole, but some folks says, that it prints fine without using supports.

HINT: You can strip really thin wires (for example from servo motor or RC flight controller (0.8 mm in diameter with insulation)) with last third of the blade, near ring for finger.

title: Headless Gourd Shaped Concert Ukulele
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
An example of 3D model generated with my Gugulele OpenSCAD script… (see https://github.com/bguan/gugulele).

  • Decorative headless unibody gourd shaped design
  • Single rectangular through-body spine
  • Single oval off center sound hole
  • T-Bracing
  • Tail-end placement of Planetary tuners
  • 3 pieces using M1.6 socket head screws

You can hear me playing the fully assembled unit in this demo youtube video: https://youtu.be/wjND_2x5BcE

Third Party Parts:

  • Spine/rods e.g. http://www.acpsales.com/.125-x-.325-Rectangular-Rod.html or https://dragonplate.com/ecart/product.asp?pID=749&cID=20
    • get a 24" long and cut it down to size, can't remember exactly...
    • if you don't use a rod, the neck will bow under string tension
  • Gotoh UPT-UBB-B Tuners e.g. http://www.theukulelesite.com/gotoh-upt-tuner-upgrade.html
    • its possible to use cheaper friction tuners, but need to play with shims and washers like this user http://www.thingiverse.com/make:325819
    • he uses https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002HFQ88Y
  • Screws (M1.6x12) for fretboard long holes e.g. http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00XP4OD5Q
    • can't remember how many you need, just buy a bag of 100
  • Screws (M1.6x4) for bridge and fretboard short (mid-line) holes e.g. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00XP4ZWY2
    • can't remember how many you need, just buy a bag of 100

I printed this on big delta style printers, the model is oriented pointing up, like a flower vase. I use 100 micron, 33% lattice infill.

OpenSCAD programming!

The hardest part for me is to deal with the lack of spline in OpenSCAD. I have to subtract scaled arc from rectangle and revolve it to get to a funnel shape for the shoulder, and similarly scaled different quadrants of sphere to get an ellipsoid. Also due to "functional" nature of OpenSCAD, I have to contort the fret calculation by using some crazy recursive function. Filleting also is a challenge as I have to accomplish that with Minkowski sum of small sphere
and the main parts with sharp edges.

The most painful part is that OpenSCAD is painfully slow when rendering at high resolution, as it is single threaded and not utilizing GPU unlike professional 3D CAD tools. I intend to port the script to a different language/tech someday e.g. OnShape Feature Script.

title: PSU Cover w/Switch and Outlet for Anet A8

description.text:
This covers the screw terminals of the Anet A8 PSU. It has a hole in the right side that corresponds with the M3 tapped hole on the side of the PSU. I used adhesive velcro strips to attach the left side, as there are no screw holes on that side.

The holes in the front of the panel accept a rocker switch and a C14 outlet. I used these:
C14 Outlets on ebay (~$2.25, 10pcs)
Rocker Switches on ebay (~$2.50, 10pcs)

I printed this on its face, with supports. Supports are needed (on my printer, at least) for the z-axis stepper motor wire cutout.

I had to scale up the iCube significantly in order for it to be compatible with the iPad. Unfortunately, I think it's much too large for most printers, at 1 m^3. Most of you will have to assemble it from the iCube-small file.

If you can, print the iCube for iPad file. This will require a printer with 1 m^3 build area.
Otherwise, print 1000 iCube-small parts and glue them together. These should print on any printer with a 100mm^3 build area.
Of course, you could scale it to any arbitrary size, but you don't get the full majesty of the design if you change it much.

title: Linear Knurled EDC Tri Spinner with Peg Cap  / Triple Bearing Spinner!

description.text:
You can buy this spinner fully assembled on our Etsy! Find it here: http://etsy.me/2eshkMD

Our first crack at making a fidget spinner! These are a ton of fun to play with, and we definitely intend to release several more models as we iterate on this design. We made the design in OpenSCAD, so the original parametric model can be easily modified.

This spinner has a peg cap, which allows you to to grip the spinner with a pinch grip, and also spin it like a top! We didn't see a similar design yet, so it seemed like a cool addition!

Just print it out and add four 608 bearings; one for the center spinner, and three for added mass around the sides!

title: Cybernetic Liberation Front (Fourth Edition Pocket-Tactics Update)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an update of our old Cybernetic Liberation Front set for the new Fourth Edition Pocket-Tactics rules. If you printed that set for the third edition stuff, you can now use the units as a faction (or in custom builds) for the new stuff!

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

-------------------------------------------------RULES-------------------------------------------------------
These units total 76 points if one of each were to be used. To use them in a standard 50 point match, the following build works nicely; (Cyber-Grunt x1, Cyberteur x1, Cyber-Doc x1, Cyber-Commando x1), though for a 100 point build, the following is a good suggested build; (Cyber-Grunt x2, Mutant Rebel x1, Cyberteur x1, Hacked Proto-Cattle x2, Cyber-Doc x1, Cyber-Commando x1). This tile build is suggested for either build; Grid tile x2, Wasteland tile x3, Water tile x1, Badland x1.

Inverted-color images of the rules cards are available here and here if you want something a little less ink-intensive.

SETTING UP

To begin, each player builds a force by selecting a number of units that total 50 points or less. For a larger game, you and your opponent could agree on a higher point total.

Next, each player chooses 6 tiles and all of the tiles are dropped into a bag and shuffled. Then, players agree (randomly, if you choose) on a “central feature” tile and then each choose a feature for themselves. (features are the 3-dimensional tiles such as Forest, Highlands, Villages, et cetera). Draw a single tile from the bag and place the central feature into that tile. Rolling off to see who goes first, players take turns drawing tiles from the bag and placing them adjacent to one another in whatever configuration they wish. Once all of the tiles have been placed, each player (in turn order decided by the roll-off) places their chosen feature so that it is both as many tiles away from the center and from one another as possible.

Once the map has been generated, players place up to three units of their choice (as many as they can fit) either in or adjacent to their chosen feature using the rolled-off turn order. You may only ever have a single unit occupy a tile or feature. Once this is finished, game play begins starting with the last player to place their units.

PLAYING THE GAME

Each turn, a player may either move one of their units, use one of their units to assault an enemy unit, or deploy a new unit onto the map.

MOVING: When activating a unit to move, they may do so into any unoccupied tile adjacent to them. If an allied unit is in an adjacent tile, the moving unit may “hop” over that unit to get to an open tile adjacent to their ally. A unit may only hop a single ally per move. Some features (Forests, Highlands, Villages, et cetera) have special movement considerations that will be listed on their rules card. Spaces that do not contain a tile may not be moved into.

SWIFT UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move.

FLYING UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move and may hop over enemy units as though they were allies when doing so.

ASSAULTS: When activating a unit to assault an adjacent enemy, each player tests their units Offense (OFF) by rolling their red dice and defense (DEF) by rolling their blue dice. A unit will have between zero and three of each kind of dice as shown on their rules cards. The assault occurs in three phases:

Roll Phase- All dice are rolled simultaneously.

Bump Phase- Some units have “bumps,” a numeric value with a + listed under either their OFF or DEF dice. Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player may take turns using a single bump. Each bump may adjust a single die result (either OFF or DEF) up by its value (though a single die may not go higher than 6). Some units may have multiple bump values listed under their dice or granted by special abilities or terrain effects.

Re-Roll Phase- Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player takes turns using any re-rolls they are afforded, either by special abilities or terrain/unit placement. Each re-roll allows the player to re-roll one of their die results (OFF or DEF). A unit that has adjacent allies is benefiting from “support” and gains one re-roll per ally. A unit also gains a single re-roll when occupying their “favored terrain” (a terrain tile or feature that is shown on their rules card).

Tally Phase- Each player checks their OFF results and checks them against the opponent's DEF results. Starting with the highest OFF die, compare it to the highest enemy DEF die. If the results are a tie, move on to the next highest. If a single OFF die can't be matched or beat by value from the enemy's DEF, that enemy is “defeated” and is removed from the map and placed in the victorious player's captures (a space to the side of the map on that player's side). If the OFF cannot beat the enemy DEF values, that unit is safe. Note that, because all dice are rolled at once, it is possible for both units to defeat one another simultaneously.

RANGED ATTACKS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may make assaults against units that are an extra number of tiles away equal to the numeric value listed to the side. Count through the closest route to get to the target before making a ranged assault. Features and enemy units block line of sight (except when a Flying unit is targeted or is making the assault) and empty spaces (spaces without a tile) always block line of sight. If a unit being assaulted is not capable of meeting the range requirements to the attacker, they may not roll their OFF dice for that assault.

DEPLOYMENT: In place of activating one of your units already on the map, you may choose a unit from your reserves (any of the units you didn't put on the map at the start of the game that haven't been captured by enemies) and place them adjacent to any feature on the map that you control (provided the space is unoccupied). If no such tile exists, you may not deploy a unit until one opens up.

Any player may, in place of performing a regular move action, move a piece into an occupied feature tile to return that unit to reserves. Similarly, a unit that is occupying a feature may move into that feature to return to reserves, though you then cede control of the feature by doing so.

TYPES

Listed directly beneath a unit's name are a number of “types” (Human, Elf, Robot, et cetera). These types have no effect on their own, though are referenced by certain abilities and terrain effects that may either be beneficial or detrimental to the unit.

HAZARDS

Some terrain tiles and features contain hazards. These are special effects that occur when a unit is moved into that tile. Units that are deployed into a tile with hazard effects ignore them, as do units that have that tile type as their favored terrain.

WATER: A unit moving into a Water tile must succeed at a DV 5 DEF test or be defeated immediately after doing so.

If a feature is placed in a terrain tile, the tile counts as that feature rather than the terrain type, and therefore negates any hazard effects native to the terrain type.

VICTORY CONDITIONS

A player achieves victory as soon as their opponent (or opponents) cannot activate or deploy any units. Alternately, victory is secured the moment any single player controls all features on the map.
